Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS nuget restore is not respecting NoWarn on package references" (#6340) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When I restore in VS, NoWarn on PackageReference has no effect.

When I restore via msbuild /t:restore, it works as expected. 

This is a regression in the 15.6 dogfood build I have. It works fine on VS 15.5.1 RTM.

## Details about Problem

* **NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe)**: VS UI
* **NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx)**: 4.6.0.??? (VS About doesn't show 4th part)
* **VS version (if appropriate):** 15.6.0 Preview 1.1 [27217.0.d15.6]
* **Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version**: Yes, worked fine in VS 15.5.1 RTM.


## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Build this project with restore having been done in VS:

``` xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp2.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NewtonSoft.Json" Version="4.5.11" NoWarn="NU1701" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

## Expected result

Builds without warnings

## Actual result
```
1>c:\users\nicholg\source\repos\ConsoleApp22\ConsoleApp22\ConsoleApp22.csproj : warning NU1701: Package 'Newtonsoft.Json 4.5.11' was 
restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1' instead of the project target framework '.NETCoreApp,Version=v2.0'. This package may not be 
fully compatible with your project.
```

cc @emgarten @davkean

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Xdt Transforms support in Package Reference" (#5954) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
XDT Transforms don't work for transitive restore 

https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd465326%28v=vs.110%29.aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396
https://blog.nuget.org/20130920/how-to-use-nugets-xdt-feature-examples-and-facts.html)

There are over 700 unique packages on nuget.org that have xml transforms.

This can't be done in PackageReference currently because the concept of install/uninstall is non existent.
Package Reference does not change any project artifacts by design!

These transforms are normally required in the published application, however we need to consider the F5 experience, since just building does not copy over the config files. 

Another concern is that not only web.config files are being transformed but also applicationinsights.xmls, UI.xml and seemingly random xmls . 

1) We can maybe do the  transform in the build targets of nuget, that way we don't have inconsistent behavior among VS and CLI/EXE. 
2) Work with the web teams to get it done on publish.

Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
